ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Literature of the Renaissance is a survey of major late medieval and early modern writers, mainly from France, Italy, and England. The quality of readings could vary a bit (why only one woman writer?), but overall I was pleased I had chosen to take the class. Professor Manley has a wealth of knowledge about the Renaissance, and he provided generous writing feedback. I did feel, however, that he could have created more space for student voices in the seminar--often he would talk for some time without interruption, and I might have preferred a more open-ended and participatory discussion format. But if you like pre-1800 lit, you will enjoy this class!

I would recommend the course to a fellow student. Why: (i) The syllabus is good: I missed only Cervantes. (ii) The class is small--I assume that it will remain around the same size in the next years--and students need to participate for it to go on. (iii) Prof. Manley knows a great deal about Renaissance literature and is interesting to talk to.

Read the syllabus. If you're interested by the authors take it. Manley knows a ton about each author and you will certainly learn a lot from him. As far as workload goes, it's pretty much the same as every other seminar.

ENGL 180 provides a solid introduction to the literature of the Renaissance. It is structured as a "great books" course, so the syllabus is designed around laying out the general ideas of the period and tracing their developments through the centuries. I would definitely recommend this course to other students; it provides the background knowledge that is necessary to understanding many later texts in the European tradition.
